Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Collaborative Research: Variation and the Grammar of Child African American English

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
The variation of language dialects has been primarily studied for adult speech. A growing literature is looking at the development of these dialects by focusing on children's usage. One reason this is important is because accurate understanding of a dialect and its acquisition and development are needed to identify typical linguistic patterns and when patterns are indicative of a language disorder. Collaborations between experts in linguistics and communication disorders have the potential to answer questions about developing patterns in children in dialects where adults use variable forms, and where the stages of development of acquisition are not yet clearly described and analyzed. This project will collect developmental data on the acquisition of a particular dialect to fill in gaps in the literature about stages of development of the acquisition of variable forms, information that is not available for the child variety of the dialect. Broader impacts include the usefulness of findings for the development of more culturally and linguistically appropriate assessment tools, leading to more accurate assessment outcomes for children who speak this dialect, the involvement in undergraduate research by underrepresented groups, and the strengthening of a research collaboration between two institutions, one a historically black college (HBCU). The activities will provide undergraduate students with background and analytical skills that are applicable to STEM-related fields, such as linguistics and computation.

This project is a collaboration between researchers from Jackson State University (an HBCU) and the University of Massachusetts Amherst to investigate developing patterns in morphological marking on verbs in African American English (AAE). Systematic variation in African American English (AAE) has been addressed in research on the variety; however, there remains a blurred line of demarcation between typical developmental language variation and language disorder in younger AAE speakers. This study builds on previous descriptions of child AAE, and it applies quantitative analysis and mechanisms in current syntactic theory to empirical data in investigating the connection between morphological marking and the instantiation of [Tense] and [Agreement] in child AAE. Specifically, the project will analyze verbs in past tense contexts and in 3rd person singular non-past contexts child AAE. The data and results will bear directly on the acquisition path of morphological marking (e.g., 3rd singular -s and forms of past such as -ed) on verbs in that it will fill gaps in the literature about stages of development of the acquisition of variable forms, information that is not available for child AAE. Findings of the project will be used to describe how normal variation associated with child AAE is systematically different from disordered language. Findings will be useful in the development of more culturally and linguistically appropriate assessment tools, leading to more accurate assessment outcomes for AAE-speaking children. A better understanding of the AAE linguistic system will be useful in addressing longstanding questions that remain unanswered about the interaction of AAE and the acquisition of literacy and other language-based academic subjects, such as math and science, and should ultimately lead to more positive educational opportunities for children who speak AAE.

POR.DRECONTENT:
African American English (AAE) (also known as African American Language) refers to a range of language varieties spoken by some?not all?African Americans. These varieties are characterized by syntactic (sentence structure), phonological (sound patterns and combination), morphological (word structure), semantic and pragmatic (meaning and use), and lexical (words) principles. A core grammar of AAE is shared by its speakers; however, a number of factors, such as level of contact with other speech communities, influence a speaker?s variety. An overwhelming majority of research on AAE focuses on the language patterns of adults. Investigation of language used by AAE-speaking school-age children started in the 1960s in response to questions about the extent to which the linguistic system differed from the standard English that was expected in the classroom and whether it was a predictor of the level of academic success. Research on language use by pre-school-age developing AAE-speaking children started in the 1970s and addressed questions about the extent to which the developing language resembled adult AAE. 

One goal of this NSF research is to develop methods and approaches that advance the study of child AAE by moving away from inappropriately comparing developing AAE to the adult language. In addition, this research begins to describe developmental patterns that children in AAE-speaking communities exhibit in the language acquisition process. The focus is on the types of verbal inflectional properties (or word endings) that 3- to 6-year-old children and their caretakers in AAE-speaking communities in southwest Louisiana use when they talk about events in past and non-past. Questions such as the following are investigated:

(1) What are the developmental properties of 3rd person singular non-past and past marking in child AAE?

(2) What is the evidence that variable forms (such as she go/she goes) are part of the developing AAE-speaking child?s grammar?

(3) What, if any, are differences in development of 3rd person singular non-past and past marking along the acquisition path? 

Data from children?s spontaneous speech, story repetition, and retell tasks were collected and analyzed. The low frequency production of 3rd person singular marking in the spontaneous speech, repetition, and story retell points in the direction that overt inflectional marking on verbs in 3rd person singular contexts is not part of the developing grammar of child AAE speakers. Also, that children begin to produce the 3rd person singular marking more frequently in the repetition task as they get older clearly shows that the children detect the inflectional marking although overt production is not always reflected in the children?s spontaneous speech or in the story retells. This research provides further insight into the stages of inflectional marking in child AAE. While children?s lack of overt inflectional marking on verbs in 3rd person singular contexts may be superficially similar to what is observed in some adult AAE speakers, the data from spontaneous speech and the other two tasks reveal differences between children?s early use of verbs to talk about events in comparison to adult structures.  

The data from this project begins to fill gaps in the linguistic and acquisition literature about properties of tense marking and agreement in developmental AAE. In addition, the data collected from the three different sources, spontaneous speech, repetition tasks, and story retells, are useful in developing workshops and instructional materials that offer guidance in addressing questions that might be raised by speech pathologists about language patterns of normally developing AAE-speaking children.
